columns.text: In this task, **we should determine how the price of Bond J and Bond K will change according to the changes in interest rates.**

First, we should calculate the current price without any changes. Then, we should change the interest rate and see how the price is related to the interest rate. We know that the price and interest rates are inversely proportional, so we expect the higher interest rate to lower the price. Let's calculate and analyze if our expectation is right.

Let's follow the formula for the bond price.

$$\text{Price}=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{-n}}{\text{YTM}}+\dfrac{\text{P}}{\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{n}}$$

C-coupon of the bond 

YTM-yield to maturity

P-par value

n-time

We should calculate the future payment of the bond, discounted at the time zero (now). The bond payment will be twice per year(semiannually), but we have an annual coupon rate and YTM. That is why we should divide the YTM and the coupon rate by two. A period is given annually, but we should multiply it by two. The bondholder will not get payments 14 times, but 28 (two times per year).

Let's adjust the periods.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual periods}&=\text{annual periods}\times2\\[15pt]
&=14\times2\\[15pt]
&=28
\end{aligned}$$

**We should insert in the formula 28 periods.**

Let's adjust YTM.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual YTM}&=\dfrac{\text{annual YTM}}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{6\%}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{3\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**The semiannual YTM is 3\%.**

Let's adjust the coupon rate of the bond J.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual coupon rate bond J}&=\dfrac{\text{annual coupon rate}}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{3\%}{2}\\[15pt]
&=1.5\%
\end{aligned}$$

The semi-annual coupon rate is 1.5\%.

Let's calculate the value of the coupon of bond J with the new coupon rate.
Coupon rates are determined by the entity that issues a bond. The coupon value will be the same for every future payment. So it is a fixed amount.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{coupon value}=&\text{coupon rate}\times\text{Face value}\\[15pt]
&=1.5\%\times\$1,000\\[15pt]
&=\$15
\end{aligned}$$

The coupon value of the bond J is \$15.

Let's adjust the coupon rate of the bond K.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual coupon rate bond K}&=\dfrac{\text{annual coupon rate}}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{9\%}{2}\\[15pt]
&=4.5\%
\end{aligned}$$

The semi-annual coupon rate is 4.5\%.

Let's calculate the value of the coupon of the bond K with the new coupon rate.
Coupon rates are determined by the entity that issues a bond. The coupon value will be the same for every future payment. So it is a fixed amount.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{coupon value}=&\text{coupon rate}\times\text{Face value}\\[15pt]
&=4.5\%\times\$1,000\\[15pt]
&=\$45
\end{aligned}$$

The coupon value of the bond K is \$45.

Let's now calculate the price of the bond J with the adjusted data.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$15\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+3\%\right)^{-28}}{3\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+3\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$15\times18.764+\$437.07\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$718.53}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond J is \$718.53.**

Let's now calculate the price of the bond K with the adjusted data.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$45\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+3\%\right)^{-28}}{3\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+3\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$45\times18.76+\$437.07\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$1,281.468}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond K is \$1,281.468.**

**a)**

Now let's calculate the price of the bond J after the interest rates are **higher by 2\%**. We should consider 8\% annual interest rates, **4\% semiannual interest rates.**

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$15\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+4\%\right)^{-28}}{4\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+4\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$15\times16.66+\$333,47\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$583.423}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond J when the interest is higher is \$583.423.**

Let's calculate the relative change of the price of the bond J after the higher interest rates.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{relative change of the price of bond J}&=\dfrac{\text{new price}-\text{old price}}{\text{old price}}\times 100\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$583.42-\$718.53}{\$718.53}\times100\\[15pt]
&=-18.80\%
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond J decreased by 18.8\%.**

Now let's calculate the price of the bond K after the interest rates are **higher by 2\%**.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$45\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+4\%\right)^{-28}}{4\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+4\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$45\times16.66+\$333.47\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$1,083.31}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond K when the interest is higher is \$1,083.31.**

Let's calculate the relative change of the price of the bond K after the higher interest rates.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{relative change of the price of bond K}&=\dfrac{\text{new price}-\text{old price}}{\text{old price}}\times 100\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$1,083.31-\$1,281.468}{\$1,281.468}\times100\\[15pt]
&=-15.46\%
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond K decreased by 15.46\%.**

**b)**


Now let's calculate the price of the bond J after the interest rates are **lower by 2\%**. We should consider 4\% annual interest rates, **2\% semiannual interest rates.**

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$15\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+2\%\right)^{-28}}{2\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+2\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$15\times21.28+\$457.377\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$893.59}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond J when the interest is lower is \$893.59**

Let's calculate the relative change of the price of the bond J after the lower interest rates.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{relative change of the price of bond J}&=\dfrac{\text{new price}-\text{old price}}{\text{old price}}\times 100\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$893.59-\$718.53}{\$718.53}\times100\\[15pt]
&=24.36\%
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond J increased by 24.36\%.**

Now let's calculate the price of the bond K after the interest rates are **lower by 2\%**.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$45\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+2\%\right)^{-28}}{2\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+2\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$45\times21.28+\$957.65\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$1,532.032}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond K when the interest is lower is \$1,532.032.**

Let's calculate the relative change of the price of the bond K after the lower interest rates.


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{relative change of the price of bond K}&=\dfrac{\text{new price}-\text{old price}}{\text{o. price}}\times 100\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$1,532.032-\$1,281.462}{\$1,281.462}\times100\\[15pt]
&=19.55\%
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the bond K increased by 19.55\%.**

**c)**

**This tells us that the bonds with lower coupon rates are more sensitive to the changes of the interest rates than the bonds with higher interest rates.**

*As we expected in the beginning, the higher interest rates will lower the price of the bond. The effect is higher on the bonds with lower coupon rates.*
